'''Fatima Babiker Mahmoud''' ({{lang-ar|فاطمة بابكر محمود}}) is a [[Sudan|Sudanese]]-born [[socialist|socialist]] [[feminism|feminist]].{{cite book|author=Fatima Sadiqi|title=Women’s Movements in Post-“Arab Spring” North Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YF5BDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA170|date=23 May 2016|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-137-50675-7|pages=170–}} == Biography == She graduated from the [[University of Khartoum]]{{cite book |last=Mahmoud |first=Fatima |date=1984 |title=The Sudanese Bourgeoisie:Vanguard of Development? |url= |location=London|publisher=Zed Books |page=back cover |isbn=978-0862321833 |}} and earned her doctorate at the [[University of Hull]].{{cite web |url= https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/african-studies-review/article/fatima-babiker-mahmoud-the-sudanese-bourgeoisievanguard-of-development-new-jersey-zed-press-ltd-1984-170-pages-2625-boards-1025-paper/2C9472FEB5BB11B2C9B36DCFD07DCC39 |title=Fatima Babiker Mahmoud. The Sudanese Bourgeoisie–Vanguard of Development? (book review) |last=Messing |first=Simon |date=March 1985 |website=African Studies Review |publisher=Cambridge University Press |access-date=11 September 2017 |}} Her doctoral thesis was the basis of her most-frequently cited work, ''The Sudanese Bourgeoisie:Vanguard of Development?'' in which she traced the historical development of the modern Sudanese bourgeoisie and concluded that it had no progressive role to play in the development of Sudan. The Pan-African Women's Liberation Organisation (PAWLO) was established at the time of the 7th Pan-African Conference in [[Kampala]], [[Uganda]] in April 1994,{{cite web |url= http://pdfproc.lib.msu.edu/?file=/DMC/African%20Journals/pdfs/political%20science/volume1n1/ajps001001006.pdf |title=Pan-African Women Organising for the Future: The Formation of the Pan African Women's Liberation Organisation and Beyond |last=Roy-Campbell |first=Zaline |date=June 1996 |website=The Afrian e-Journals Project |publisher=University of Michigan |access-date=11 September 2017 |}} and Dr Mahmoud became its founding President. Addressing the first meeting of PAWLO, she said:
"African women share a common history, a common conceptual framework in understanding our reality in order to change it, and common enemies and friends within and outside Africa. We have similar challenges to face and a better future to look forward to. There is now a serious need for a new Pan African Women's organisation, embracing African women on the continent and in the diaspora, to address these commonalities."
Dr. Mahmoud has previously served as a member of the Editorial Advisory Board for the ''[[Journal of Gender Studies]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09589236.1996.9960638?journalCode=cjgs20 |title=Editorial Board, Journal of Gender Studies |author= |date=28 April 2010 |website=tandfonline.com |publisher=Taylor & Francis|access-date=11 September 2017 |}} ==Selected writing== *المرأة الافريقية بين الارث والحداثة (''African Women Between Heritage and Modernity'') (2002) *[http://www.worldcat.org/title/african-women-transformation-and-development/oclc/29799162 ''African Women, Transformation and Development'' (1991)] *[http://www.worldcat.org/title/calamity-in-the-sudan-civilian-versus-military-rule/oclc/20555164 ''Calamity in the Sudan: Civilian Versus Military Rule'' (1988)] *[http://www.worldcat.org/title/sudanese-bourgeoisie-vanguard-of-development/oclc/11574930 ''The Sudanese Bourgeoisie: Vanguard of Development?'' (1984)] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control|VIAF=275437652}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mahmoud, Fatima Babiker}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Sudanese expatriates]] [[Category:Sudanese feminists]] [[Category:Sudanese socialists]] [[Category:Pan-Africanism]] {{Sudan-bio-stub}}

{{animal testing}} The '''Foundation for Biomedical Research''' (FBR) is an [[United States|American]] non profit organization, [[501(c)(3)]], located in Washington, DC. Established in 1981, the organization is dedicated to informing the news media, teachers, and other groups about the need for lab animals in medical and scientific research. The organization, together with its partner, the [http://www.nabr.org/ National Association for Biomedical Research] (NABR), argues that promoting animal research leads to improved health for both humans and animals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fbresearch.org/AboutFBR/tabid/423/Default.aspx| title=About FBR |author = Foundation for Biomedical Research| accessdate = 2009-06-24}}</ref>
Its founding president is [[Frankie Trull]].
==Animal research== According to the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), the total number of animals used in that country in 2005 was almost 1.2 million,<ref name="USDA2006">[http://www.aphis.usda.gov/animal_welfare/downloads/awreports/awreport2005.pdf 2005 Report on Enforcement of the Animal Welfare Act] ''U.S. Department of Agriculture'', Accessed 8 February 2008</ref> excluding rats and mice.<ref>The humane care and treatment of laboratory animals {{cite web |url=http://www.nabr.org/pdf/orange.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-03-08 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080308163109/http://www.nabr.org/pdf/orange.pdf |archivedate=March 8, 2008 |df= }} ''National Association of Biomedical Research'', Accessed 8 February 2008</ref><ref name="Trull">{{cite journal|last2=Rich|first2=Barbara A.|year=1999|title=More Regulation of Rodents|url=|journal=Science|volume=284|issue=5419|page=1463|doi=10.1126/science.284.5419.1463|last1=Trull|first1=Frankie L.}}</ref> Some [[animal rights]] supporters believe that [[Alternatives to animal testing|alternatives]] exist for animal models in research; however the vast majority of scientists believe there are no adequate alternatives which truly replace the roles which research animals play.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animalresearch.info/en/medical/lectures/Animalresearchandmedicalprogress | title=Animal research and medical progress | author=Sir John Vane}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aboutanimaltesting.co.uk/scientists-against-animal-testing.html/| title=Scientists Against Animal Testing | author=About animal testing}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfn.org/index.aspx?pagename=guidelinesPolicies_UseOfAnimalsandHumans/| title=Policies on the Use of Animals and Humans in Neuroscience Research |author=The Society for Neuroscience}}</ref> In fact, recent research shows that 98% of the current drug pipeline relies on either dogs or non-human primates. [[File:The-Critical-Role-of-Monkeys-in-Medical-Research-Infographic.gif|thumb|This graphic depicts several advances made with nonhuman primate research and a series of pie charts which show the percentages of total lab animals by species.]] According to the Foundation for Biomedical Research, animal research has been responsible for every medical breakthrough over the past century, although this position has been disputed by some animal rights activists and organizations.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Ruesch|first=Hans|title=1000 Doctors (and many more) Against Vivisection|publisher = Civis/Civitas| asin= B000FJGF82|year=1989}}</ref><ref>Animal Experimentation Issues PCRM {{cite web |url=http://www.pcrm.org/resch/anexp/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723001342/http://www.pcrm.org/resch/anexp/index.html |archivedate=July 23, 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://caat.jhsph.edu/about/index.htm| title= The Johns Hopkins Center for Alternatives to Animal Testing (CAAT)|accessdate= 2009-06-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://petaliterature.com/VIV230.pdf| title=Animals in Experimentation – Everybody Loses| author = PETA|accessdate=2009-06-24}}</ref> It cites animal research as leading to advances in antibiotics, blood transfusions, dialysis, organ transplantation, vaccinations, chemotherapy, bypass surgery, joint replacement, and methods for prevention, treatment, cure and control of disease, pain and suffering.
=== Nonhuman primates === Nonhuman primates have been at the forefront of animal research controversy over the last several years even though they represent less than one percent of all animals models used.<ref name=":0">The Critical Role of Nonhuman Primates in Research, https://fbresearch.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/NHP-White-Paper-Print-08-22-16.pdf. pg. 11.</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://monkeyresearch.org/|title=MONKEYRESEARCH.ORG|website=monkeyresearch.org|access-date=2017-02-21}}</ref> In August 2016, to counter criticism from animal rights' groups, a white paper coauthored by nine of the most premier scientific groups and titled ''[https://fbresearch.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/NHP-White-Paper-Print-08-22-16.pdf The Critical Role of Nonhuman Primates in Medical Research]'' was released.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://fbresearch.org/nine-science-advocacy-groups-release-white-paper-critical-role-nonhuman-primates-nhps-scientific-medical-research/|title=Nine Premier Scientific Groups Release White Paper on the Critical Role of Nonhuman Primates (NHPs) in Scientific and Medical Research - Foundation for Biomedical Research|date=2016-08-24|newspaper=Foundation for Biomedical Research|access-date=2017-02-21|language=en-US}}</ref> Because of their incredible similarity to humans, primates such as rhesus macaques and chimpanzees, up until the [[National Institutes of Health]] ended public funding for chimpanzee research,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nih.gov/about-nih/who-we-are/nih-director/statements/nih-will-no-longer-support-biomedical-research-chimpanzees|title=NIH Will No Longer Support Biomedical Research on Chimpanzees|date=2015-11-18|newspaper=National Institutes of Health (NIH)|access-date=2017-02-21|language=en}}</ref> have greatly contributed to many areas of medicine. Some specific advances, according to the white paper, are: the development of the [[MMR vaccine]], the treatment of [[leprosy]], [[Management of HIV/AIDS|HIV medication]], a vaccine for [[hepatitis B]], and improvements in cancer treatment.<ref>The Critical Role of Nonhuman Primates in Medical Research, https://fbresearch.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/NHP-White-Paper-Print-08-22-16.pdf. pg. 9-10.</ref><ref>https://fbresearch.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/Benefits-of-Monkey-Research-online-brochure.pdf</ref> One of the most recent advancements has been the development of a highly effective vaccine against the [[Zika virus]], which should soon be protecting both the people and primates that are most at risk of infection.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/2120160-powerful-zika-vaccine-protects-mice-and-monkeys-from-the-virus/|title=Powerful Zika vaccine protects mice and monkeys from the virus|newspaper=New Scientist|access-date=2017-02-21|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Dogs === Dogs have been used in research for decades and have been invaluable for treating many human and canine illnesses. Dogs contract many of the diseases humans do, from heart disease to cancer and they are also exposed to the same environment as humans. Canine research has led to many significant breakthroughs such as [[hip replacement]]s, development of cancer treatments, and research in [[stem cell]]s, [[Diabetes mellitus|diabetes]], and [[Alzheimer's disease]].<ref>Dogs: The Essential Need for Animals in Medical Research, https://fbresearch.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/Dogs-In-Biomedical-Research-FBR.pdf</ref> Treatments for [[Dirofilaria immitis|heartworms]], parasites, and vaccinations against [[parvovirus]], [[rabies]], and [[canine distemper]] have also come from canine models.<ref name=":1"/>
=== Cats === Cats, like dogs, have also proven to be extremely helpful for developing treatments for both human and feline diseases. Cats have been a mainstay in research studies of neurological, cardiovascular, and respiratory diseases and the immune system. In particular, they have been valuable models for understanding the function of the [[neuron]], the chemical transmission of nerve impulses, and the functional organization of the brain. Neuroscientists studying cats have provided a map of the circuitry of the vertebral cortex revealing the major pathways that send signals from the eye to the brain.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nabr.org/biomedical-research/laboratory-animals/species-in-research/cats/|title=Cats {{!}} NABR|website=www.nabr.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-21}}</ref> Cats have also been invaluable for the treatment of [[leukemia]] and both feline and human breast cancer.<ref name=":2" /> [[Feline leukemia virus|Feline leukemia]] used to be one of the most common killers of cats and about 85% died within three years of their diagnosis. However, with their help, scientists have developed a vaccine for feline leukemia and now more beloved pets get to spend more time with their families.
=== Rodents === In the U.S., the numbers of rats and mice used in animal research is estimated at 20 million a year, or 95% of the total number of lab animals.<ref name="Trull" /><ref name=":0" /> Other rodents commonly used are guinea pigs, hamsters, and gerbils. Mice are the most commonly used vertebrate species because of their size, low cost, ease of handling, and fast reproduction rate.<ref name="Rosenthal">{{cite journal | last1 = Rosenthal | first1 = N | last2 = Brown | first2 = S | title = The mouse ascending: perspectives for human-disease models. | journal = Nature Cell Biology | volume = 9 | issue = 9 | pages = 993–9 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17762889 | doi = 10.1038/ncb437 }}</ref> Mice also have genomes that are very similar to the human genome. This similarity allows researchers to recreate human diseases, such as breast cancer, in mice in order to understand how genes affect the development of disease.<ref name=":1" /> The Foundation advocates the highest quality of animal care and treatment, stating that the use of animals in research is a privilege, and that animals deserve our respect and the best possible care.
== Activities == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:ALF-W.B. Saul Agricultural High School, April 2004.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Message left in April 2004 on the wall of dogs' kennels by the [[Animal Liberation Front]], the kind of activity that the Foundation for Biomedical Research seeks to counteract]] --> The Foundation for Biomedical Research conducts educational programs for the news media, teachers, students and parents, pet owners and other groups.
FBR publishes a subscriber-based daily news service called Total E-clips featuring biomedical research news, medical breakthroughs, political and legislative and activism news.
Since 1981, the FBR has monitored and analyzed the activities of animal rights organizations relating to researchers and institutions. {{clear}}

'''Franciszek Salezy Krupiński''' (January 22, 1836, Łukowie near [[Siedlce]]–August 16, 1898, [[Warsaw]]) was a [[Poland|Polish]] [[philosopher]].<ref name="Krupiński, Franciszek p. 612">"Krupiński, Franciszek," ''Encyklopedia Powszechna PWN'' (PWN Universal Encyclopedia), vol. 2, p. 612.</ref>
==Life== Krupiński was an early representative of [[Positivism in Poland|Polish Positivism]]. He preached "organic work" and (though himself a [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholic priest]]) fought against [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholic]] and [[Polish Romanticism|Romantic]] philosophy.<ref name="Krupiński, Franciszek p. 612"/>
==Works== *''Filozofia w Polsce'' (Philosophy in Poland; 1863) *''Szkoła pozytywna'' (The Positive School; 1868) *''Romantyzm i jego skutki'' ([[Romanticism in Poland|Romanticism]] and Its Consequences; 1876) *''Nasza historiozofia'' (Our Philosophy of History; 1876).<ref name="Krupiński, Franciszek p. 612"/>
==See also== *[[History of philosophy in Poland#Positivism|History of philosophy in Poland]] *[[List of Poles#Philosophy|List of Poles]]
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==References== *"Krupiński, Franciszek," ''Encyklopedia Powszechna PWN'' (PWN Universal Encyclopedia), [[Warsaw]], [[Państwowe Wydawnictwo Naukowe]], vol. 2, 1974, p. 612.

December 31, 2015.</ref> |employees = 30<ref name= 990-2015/> |employees_year = 2015 |volunteers = 11<ref name= 990-2015/> |volunteers_year = 2015 |revenue = $4,931,682<ref name= 990-2015/> |revenue_year = 2015 |expenses = $3,765,032<ref name= 990-2015/> |expenses_year = 2015 |endowment = $2,678,681<ref name= 990-2015/> |affiliations = Nonbelief Relief Inc<ref name= 990-2015/> <sub>([[501(c)(3)]])</sub> |formation = {{start date and age|1978}} |type = [[Non-profit organization|Non-profit]] |status = [[501(c)(3)]] educational organization<ref name= irs-eos>"[https://apps.irs.gov/app/eos/pub78Search.do?ein1=39-1302520&names=&city=&state=All...&country=US&deductibility=all&dispatchMethod=searchCharities&submitName=Search Freedom From Religion Foundation Inc.]" ''Exempt Organizations Select Check''. [[Internal Revenue Service]]. Retrieved August 5, 2017.</ref> |purpose = [[Separation of church and state]], [[nontheism]], [[atheist|atheism]], [[secularism]] |headquarters = [[Madison, Wisconsin]], [[United States of America|United States]]<ref name= 990-2015/> |region_served = [[United States]] |membership = 32,000 members<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cruz|first1=Rachel|title=Atheist group wants Ohio religious mural taken down|url=https://www.christiandaily.com/article/atheist-group-wants-ohio-religious-mural-taken-down/62107.htm|publisher=Christian Daily|accessdate=12 March 2018}}</ref> |leader_name = [[Annie Laurie Gaylor]]<ref name= who>"[https://ffrf.org/about/getting-acquainted/#who-we-are Who We Are - Executive Board of Directors]". ''Freedom From Religion Foundation''. Retrieved August 5, 2017.</ref> |leader_title = [[President (corporation)|Co-president]] |leader_name2 = [[Dan Barker]]<ref name= who/> |leader_title2= [[President (corporation)|Co-president]] |leader_name3 = Stephen Hirtle<ref name= who/> |leader_title3= [[Chairman|Chair]], [[Board of Directors]] |founder = [[Anne Nicol Gaylor]]<ref name= who/> |founded = {{start date and age|1976}} |website = {{official URL}} }}
The '''Freedom From Religion Foundation''' ('''FFRF''') is an American non-profit organization based in [[Madison, Wisconsin]], with members from all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico.<ref name= "triblive1">{{cite news |title= Those who don't believe just as adamant as religious folk |url= http://triblive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/news/westmoreland/s_789342.html |last= Aubele |first= Michael |newspaper= [[Pittsburgh Tribune-Review]] |date= April 1, 2012 |accessdate= June 30, 2013}}</ref> The largest<ref>{{cite web|last1=Goins-Phillips|first1=Tré|title=University rejects atheists' claim that Vatican trip is unconstitutional|url=https://www.theblaze.com/news/2017/04/27/university-rejects-atheists-claim-that-vatican-trip-is-unconstitutional/|publisher=TheBlaze|accessdate=30 April 2017}}</ref> national organization advocating for non-theists, FFRF promotes the [[separation of church and state]] and educates the public on matters relating to [[atheism]], [[agnosticism]], and [[nontheism]]. The FFRF publishes a newspaper, ''Freethought Today'' 10 times a year.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://ffrf.org/publications/freethought-today | title=Freethought Today | publisher=Freedom From Religion Foundation | accessdate=March 24, 2017}}</ref> Since 2006, as the Freethought Radio Network, FFRF has produced the ''Freethought Radio'' show.
==History== [[File:Dan Barker introduces the FFRF.webm|thumb|[[Dan Barker]] introduces himself and the FFRF in London, July 2017.]] The FFRF was co-founded by [[Anne Nicol Gaylor]] and her daughter, [[Annie Laurie Gaylor]], in 1976 and was incorporated nationally on April 15, 1978.<ref name= corp>"[https://www.wdfi.org/apps/CorpSearch/Details.aspx?entityID=6F09055&hash=323751401&searchFunctionID=89065bfa-1f2e-4fad-ae59-11a3c0d78a46&type=Simple&q=Freedom+From+Religion+Foundation Freedom From Religion Foundation, Inc.]" ''Wisconsin Department of Financial Institutions''. Retrieved August 5, 2017.</ref><ref name="aboutCalling">{{cite news |title= The atheists' calling the Madison-based Freedom From Religion Foundation is taking its latest battle to the U.S. Supreme court. It's a milestone for the often-vilified but financially strong group, which has seen its membership grow to an all-time high. |url= http://host.madison.com/news/the-atheists-calling-the-madison-based-freedom-from-religion-foundation/article_85a849c9-f26a-50e8-8a04-cf8bc889d8a0.html |date= February 25, 2010 |last= Erickson |first= Doug |newspaper= [[Wisconsin State Journal]] |location= Madison |accessdate= June 30, 2013 }}</ref> The organization is supported by over 23,500 members<ref name="captimes1">{{cite news |last= Elbow |first= Steven |title= Crime and Courts: Madison group ramps up national fight against religion in government |url= http://host.madison.com/news/local/crime_and_courts/blog/crime-and-courts-madison-group-ramps-up-national-fight-against/article_795c5fd8-dbec-11e1-b406-001a4bcf887a.html |newspaper= [[The Capital Times]] |location= Madison, Wisconsin |accessdate= June 29, 2013 |date= August 2, 2012}}</ref> and operates from an 1855-era building in [[Madison, Wisconsin]], that once served as a church rectory. According to the 2011 IRS tax Form-990,<ref>{{cite web |last= Gaylor |first= Annie Laurie|authorlink=Annie Laurie Gaylor|date= March 5, 2012 |title= Return of Organization Exempt From Income Tax (IRS form 990) |url= https://ffrf.org/uploads/files/2011-990-form.pdf |accessdate= June 30, 2013| work= ffrf.org|postscript=.}}</ref> FFRF spent just over $200,000 on legal fees and services and just under $1 million on education, outreach, publishing, broadcasting, and events. The allotment for legal fees is primarily used in cases supporting the [[separation of church and state]] that involve governmental entities. FFRF also has a paid staff of twenty two, including five full-time staff attorneys and two legal fellows.<ref>{{cite web |title= About FFRF: Getting Acquainted |url= https://ffrf.org/about/getting-acquainted/ |work= ffrf.org |accessdate= June 30, 2013 |author= <!-- no byline FFRF staff -->}}</ref>
[[Annie Laurie Gaylor]], co-president of the FFRF, is the author of ''Women Without Superstition: No Gods - No Masters'' and the nonfiction book on clergy pedophilia scandals ''Betrayal of Trust: Clergy Abuse of Children'' (out of print) and editor of the anthology ''Woe to the Women''. She edited the FFRF newspaper ''Freethought Today'' until July 2008. Her husband, [[Dan Barker]], author of ''Losing Faith in Faith: From Preacher to Atheist'', ''Godless: How an Evangelical Preacher Became One of America's Leading Atheists'', ''The Good Atheist: Living a Purpose-Filled Life Without God'', "Life Driven Purpose", "God: The Most Unpleasant Character in all Fiction" and ''Just Pretend: A Freethought Book for Children'', is a musician and songwriter, a former [[Pentecostal]] Christian minister, and co-president of FFRF.
In March 2011, FFRF, along with the [[Richard Dawkins Foundation for Reason and Science]], began [[The Clergy Project]], a confidential on-line community that supports clergy as they leave their faith.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.clergyproject.org/ | title=The Clergy Project | accessdate= August 6, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2012-04-30/national/35451816_1_pastors-daniel-dennett-faith | title=For clergy, lost faith can lead to lost family, jobs | newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] | date=April 30, 2012 | accessdate=August 6, 2013 | last=Winston | first=Kimberly | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131216054008/http://articles.washingtonpost.com/2012-04-30/national/35451816_1_pastors-daniel-dennett-faith | archivedate=December 16, 2013 | df= }}</ref> In 2012, it gave its first Freedom From Religion Foundation and Clergy Project "Hardship Grant" to [[Jerry DeWitt]], a former pastor who left the ministry to join the atheist movement.<ref>{{cite web |title= Jerry DeWitt receives Freedom from Religion Foundation, Clergy Project Hardship Grant |url= http://www.clergyproject.org/news/2012/10/31/jerry-dewitt-receives-freedom-from-religion-foundation-clergy-project-hardship-grant/ |work= The Clergy Project website |author= <!-- no byline The Clergy Project staff --> |date= October 31, 2012 |accessdate= June 30, 2013 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130602235512/http://www.clergyproject.org/news/2012/10/31/jerry-dewitt-receives-freedom-from-religion-foundation-clergy-project-hardship-grant/ |archivedate= June 2, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
In June 2013 FFRF announced that, along with the [[Secular Student Alliance]], it would work on educating students on their religious rights and would assist with rectifying violations and what they have termed "religious infringement into public education".<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.secularstudents.org/nationalorgspartner | title=In Response to Mounting Violations, National Orgs Vow to Protect Atheist Students' Rights | publisher= [[Secular Student Alliance]] | date=June 27, 2013 | accessdate=June 30, 2013}}</ref>
In 2015, FFRF announced Nonbelief Relief, a new charitable arm. Nonbelief Relief is a humanitarian agency for atheists, agnostics, freethinkers and their supporters "to improve this world, our only world". Nonbelief Relief seeks to remediate conditions of human suffering and injustice on a global scale, whether the result of natural disasters, human actions or adherence to religious dogma.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ffrf.org/donate/nonbelief-relief-inc|title=Nonbelief Relief Inc.|website=Freedom From Religion Foundation|accessdate=15 October 2017}}</ref>
==Litigation==
===Social programs===
====Social services==== {{Main|Hein v. Freedom From Religion Foundation}} In June 2004, the FFRF challenged the constitutionality of the [[White House Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives]]. The Foundation's complaint alleged that "the use of money appropriated by Congress under [[Taxing and Spending Clause|Article I, section 8]], to fund conferences that various executive branch agencies hold to promote President Bush's 'Faith-Based and Community Initiatives'" conflicted with the First Amendment.<ref name="Pet. Cert"/> The suit held that "the defendant officials violated the [[Establishment Clause of the First Amendment|Establishment Clause]] by organizing national and regional conferences at which faith-based organizations allegedly "are singled out as being particularly worthy of federal funding because of their religious orientation, and the belief in God is extolled as distinguishing the claimed effectiveness of faith-based social services".<ref name ="Pet. Cert">{{cite web|title=Petition for a writ of certiorari, Case No. 06-157|first= Paul D. |last= Clement|url= http://www.usdoj.gov/osg/briefs/2006/2pet/7pet/2006-0157.pet.aa.pdf |publisher= Office of the [[United States Solicitor General|Solicitor General]], [[United States Department of Justice]]}}</ref> The FFRF also alleged that "the defendant officials 'engage in myriad activities, such as making public appearances and giving speeches, throughout the United States, intended to promote and advocate for funding for faith-based organizations."<ref name="Pet. Cert"/> The FFRF further asserted, "Congressional appropriations [are] used to support the activities of the defendants."<ref name="Pet. Cert"/><ref>{{cite news | url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2007-02-28/news/0702280128_1_faith-based-freedom-from-religion-foundation-supreme-court | title=Test for faith-based programs | newspaper=Chicago Tribune | date=27 February 2007 | accessdate=31 August 2013 | author=Demirjian, Karoun}}</ref> In 2007 the Supreme Court ruled 5-4 that taxpayers do not have the right to challenge the constitutionality of expenditures made by the executive branch.<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Hein v. Freedom From Religion Foundation |date= June 25, 2007 |reporter= U.S. |court= U.S. |volume= 127 |opinion= 2553 |url= https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=2489373040996353778}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title= Slamming the courthouse door on church-state cases? |journal= [[American Humanist Association|The Humanist]] |date= March–April 2007 |volume= 67 |issue= 2 |page= 38 |last= Boston |first= Rob}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2007-03-01/news/0703010206_1_faith-based-supreme-court-freedom-from-religion-foundation | title=Faith-based case divides justices | publisher=Chicago Tribune | date=1 March 2007 | accessdate=31 August 2013 | author=Demirjian, Karoun}}</ref>
In May 2007, the FFRF, on behalf of Indiana taxpayers, challenged the creation of a [[chaplain]]cy pilot program for the Indiana Family and Social Services Administration (FSSA). The FSSA hired Pastor Michael L. Latham, a [[Baptist]] minister, in 2006, at a salary of $60,000 a year. In September 2007, in response to the FFRF's suit, Indiana ended the program.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/28/us/28indiana.html?ref=us | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | title=Indiana, faced with suit, takes chaplain off payroll | first=Neela | last=Banerjee | date=September 28, 2007 | accessdate=July 1, 2013}}</ref>
====Health care==== In April 2003, the FFRF, on behalf of Montana residents, sued the Montana Office of Rural Health and its executive director David M. Young along with the [[Montana State University|Montana State University-Bozeman]] and the Montana Faith-Health Cooperative. It was alleged that Young favored faith-based nursing parish programs for state funding.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.abpnews.com/archives/item/1248-federal-judge-strikes-down-montana-faith-based-program | title=Federal judge strikes down Montana 'faith-based' program | publisher=[[Associated Baptist Press]] | date= November 2, 2004 | accessdate= July 31, 2013 | author=<!-- no byline Associated Baptist Press staff -->}}</ref> In October 2004, the Federal District Court for the District of Montana held that the state's "direct and preferential funding of inherently and pervasively religious parish nursing programs was undertaken for the impermissible purpose, and has the impermissible effect, of favoring and advancing the integration of religion into the provision of secular health care services." According to the court, the state funding of faith-based healthcare violated the First Amendment.<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Freedom From Religion Foundation v. Montana Office of Rural Health |vol= |reporter= |opinion= No. CV 03-30-BU-RWA |court= D. Mont. |date= |url= }}[https://ffrf.org/uploads/legal/montanadecision.html Memorandum and Order], October 26, 2004. Retrieved July 1, 2013.</ref>
In April 2006, the FFRF sued to challenge the pervasive integration of "spirituality" into health care by the Department of Veteran Affairs. Specifically stating that the practice of asking patients about their religion in spiritual assessments, the use of chaplains to treat patients, and drug and alcohol treatment programs that incorporate religion violated the separation of state and church.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://readingeagle.com/article.aspx?id=101852 | title=Court rejects suit opposing religion in veterans' care | newspaper=[[Reading Eagle]] | date= August 9, 2008 | accessdate= August 1, 2013 | agency=[[Associated Press]] |author= <!-- no byline AP Staff -->}}</ref> The case was later dismissed after the [[Hein v. Freedom From Religion Foundation|Hein]] decision because of lack of standing.<ref name="FFRF v Nicholson 7th">{{cite court |litigants= Freedom From Religion Foundation v. Nicholson |date= August 5, 2008 |court= 7th Cir. |url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-7th-circuit/1209983.html |opinion= 07-1292}}</ref>
====Education==== In 2001, the FFRF, on behalf of anonymous plaintiffs, sued the Rhea County School District. The plaintiffs alleged that weekly bible classes were being held for all students in the elementary schools.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7igqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OUgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3597,784968&dq=rhea+county+board+of+education+ffrf&hl=en | title=Federal appeals court in Tennessee affirms ban on Bible class at county's public schools |location= Bowling Green, KY | newspaper=Daily News | date= June 7, 2004 | accessdate= August 1, 2013 | last=Poovey |first= Bill}}</ref> In June 2004, the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed a district judgment holding that it was unconstitutional for the school district to "teach the Bible as literal truth" to students, including first graders.<ref name="FFRF v_Doe">{{cite court |litigants= Doe v. Porter |vol= 370 |reporter= F.3d |opinion= 558 |court= 6th Cir. |date= June 7, 2004 |url= http://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F3/370/558/522158/ |accessdate= July 1, 2013}}</ref>
In March 2005, the FFRF filed suit against the University of Minnesota because of its involvement with the Minnesota Faith Health Consortium, a partnership with Luther Seminary, which is affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church of America, and Fairview Health Services, stating that state taxpayer funds are helping to fund a faith-based organization. In September 2005 the University agreed to end the partnership and to cease teaching "courses on the intersection of faith and health", with the FFRF agreeing to drop its lawsuit.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lederman|first=Doug|title=Faith and health part II|url=http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2005/09/12/minn|work=[[Inside Higher Ed]] |date= September 12, 2005|accessdate=July 1, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Malladi|first=Sundeep|title=Madison-based group sues University of Minnesota|url=http://badgerherald.com/news/2005/03/31/madisonbased_group_s.php|newspaper=[[The Badger Herald]] |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070307033401/http://badgerherald.com/news/2005/03/31/madisonbased_group_s.php |archivedate= March 7, 2007 |date= March 31, 2005|postscript=. |location= Madison, WI}}</ref>
In April 2005, the FFRF filed a lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Education because of its distribution of funds to the Alaska Christian College, a Bible college run by the Evangelical Covenant Church of Alaska. The foundation stated that in the students' first year at the college, they take only religious-based courses, and finish that year with a Certificate of Biblical Studies. The college, the foundation says, "does not offer traditional college courses, such as math or English".<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2005/04/28/alaska | title=Church, state and the academic pork barrel | work=Inside Higher Ed | date= April 28, 2005 | accessdate= August 1, 2013 | last=Lederman |first= Doug}}</ref> In October 2005 the FFRF and the U.S. Department of Education settled the lawsuit, with the Department of Education agreeing not to distribute $435,000{{Clarify|reason=Was that the entire amount under controversy, or were some federal funds still distributed, and if so, how much?|date=February 2016}} of federal funds to the College.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lederman|first=Doug|title=Education Dept. suspends grant to Christian college|url=http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2005/10/11/alaska|work=Inside Higher Ed|accessdate= July 1, 2013 |date= October 11, 2005}}</ref>
====Criminal justice programs==== In October 2000, the FFRF brought suit, as taxpayers in the state of Wisconsin, against Faith Works located in Milwaukee. Their case stated that a faith-based addiction-treatment program should not be used as a court ordered treatment program using taxpayer funds.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1683&dat=20001014&id=BjYqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pi8EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6648,3435895 | title=Funding of Faith Works challenged | newspaper=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] | date= October 14, 2000 | accessdate= July 31, 2013 | last=Murphy |first= Kevin}}</ref> In January 2002 the ruling was decided in the FFRF's favor; that receiving hundreds of thousands of dollars in public money is in violation of the Establishment Clause. The judge wrote "Because I find that the Department of Workforce Development's grant to Faith Works constitutes unrestricted, direct funding of an organization that engages in religious indoctrination, I conclude that this funding stream violates the establishment clause."<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Freedom From Religion Foundation v.McCallum |vol= 179 |reporter= F.Supp.2nd |opinion= 950 |pinpoint= |court= W.D. Wis. |date= January 7, 2002 |url= http://www.leagle.com/decision-result/?xmldoc/20021129179FSupp2d950_11052.xml/docbase/CSLWAR2-1986-2006 |accessdate= July 1, 2013 |quote=}}</ref> On Appeal, in April 2003, The Seventh Circuit later ruled against the FFRF on the narrower issue of whether prisoners joining specific faith-based programs on their own free will are coerced by government endorsement of religion.<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Freedom From Religion Foundation v. McCallum |vol= 324 |reporter= F.3d |opinion= 880 |court= 7th Cir. |date= April 2, 2003 |url= https://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F3/324/324.F3d.880.02-3102.html |accessdate= July 1, 2013}}</ref>
The FFRF brought a suit against the awarding of a federal grant to MentorKids USA, a group providing mentors to children of prisoners, alleging that only Christian mentors were hired and that they were to give monthly reports on the children's religious activities.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=J9RIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XQINAAAAIBAJ&pg=3565,1022175&dq=mentor+kids+ffrf&hl=en | title=Faith-based Grant to Arizona Group Blocked | newspaper=The Madison Courier | date= January 5, 2005 | accessdate= August 1, 2013 | last=Ross |first= JR |agency= Associated Press}}</ref> In January 2005, the court vacated HHS's funding of this group citing "federal funds have been used by the MentorKids program to advance religion in violation of the Establishment Clause".<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Freedom From Religion Foundation v. Towey |vol= |reporter= |opinion= No. 04-C-381-S |court= W.D. Wis. |date= |url= |accessdate= July 1, 2013}} [http://charitygovernance.blogs.com/charity_governance/files/mentorkids_memorandum_decision.pdf Memorandum and Order] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005015301/http://charitygovernance.blogs.com/charity_governance/files/mentorkids_memorandum_decision.pdf |date=2013-10-05 }}, January 11, 2005. Retrieved July 1, 2013.</ref>
In May 2006 the FFRF filed suit against the [[Federal Bureau of Prisons]] alleging that its decision to fund not only multi-faith-based but also single-faith-based programs violated constitutional standards for separation of state and church.<ref>{{cite news |title= FFRF lawsuit halts federal faith prison program |date= November 9, 2006 |work= Freethought Today |volume= 23 |issue= 9 |url= https://ffrf.org/publications/freethought-today/item/13095-ffrf-lawsuit-halts-federal-faith-prison-program |accessdate= July 1, 2013 |publisher= FFRF}}</ref> The parties later agreed to a dismissal of that claim, but additional counts within the lawsuit, alleging separate violations, continued.<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Freedom From Religion Foundation v. Gonzales |vol= |reporter= |opinion= 06-C-0244-S |url= |court= W.D. Wis. |date= 2006}} [http://www.clearinghouse.net/chDocs/public/PC-WI-0007-0001.pdf Complaint], May 4, 2006. Retrieved July 1, 2013.</ref><ref name="Sullivan2011">{{cite book |last=Sullivan |first=Winnifred Fallers |title=Prison Religion: Faith-Based Reform and the Constitution |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DIPABj6w2O4C&pg=PA242 |accessdate=July 1, 2013 |date=September 6, 2011 |publisher=[[Princeton University Press]] |isbn=978-1-4008-3037-4 |page=242}}</ref>
===Religion in the public sphere===
====Employment issues==== In 1995 the FFRF sued the state of Wisconsin for designating Good Friday as a state legal holiday. In 1996 the federal district court ruled that Wisconsin's Good Friday holiday was indeed a First Amendment violation because the "promotion of Christianity is the primary purpose of the law."<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Freedom From Religion Foundation v. Thompson |vol= 920 |reporter= F.Supp. |opinion= 969 |court= W.D. Wis. |date= February 23, 1996 |url= http://www.leagle.com/decision-result/?xmldoc/19961889920FSupp969_11749.xml/docbase/CSLWAR2-1986-2006 |accessdate= July 1, 2013}}</ref>
====Religious displays on public property==== In December 2007 the FFRF, on behalf of a group of concerned Green Bay residents and invoking the First Amendment rights of all of the city's residents, sued the city because of the placement of a nativity scene at Green Bay's city hall. Before the case was heard, the city removed the nativity scene. The judge then dismissed the suit, citing lack of jurisdiction. Since the nativity scene already was removed and a moratorium imposed on future such displays, there remained no basis for continued dispute. He went on to say, "''the plaintiffs have already won''. ...the Plaintiffs have won a concrete victory that changes the circumstances on the ground."<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Freedom From Religion Foundation v. City of Green Bay |vol= |reporter= |opinion= 07-C-1151 |date= 2008 |court= E.D. Wis.}} [https://ffrf.org/uploads/legal/GBnativitydecision.pdf Decision and Order Granting Defendants' Motion to Dismiss], October 7, 2008. Retrieved July 1, 2013.</ref>
In 2011 in response to the city of Warren, Michigan's refusal to remove a [[Nativity scene|nativity display]] in the civic center, the FFRF sought to place a winter solstice display. The mayor refused the request and the FFRF brought suit. The suit was dismissed by Judge Zatkoff of the U.S. District Court; the dismissal was upheld by the U.S. 6th Circuit Court in 2013.<ref name="FFRF_v_Warren6th">{{cite court |litigants= Freedom From Religion Foundation v. City of Warren |court= 6th Cir. |opinion= 12-1858 |date= February 25, 2013 |url= http://www.ca6.uscourts.gov/opinions.pdf/13a0049p-06.pdf}}</ref>
In September 2011, the FFRF, along with the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] (ACLU), sued the [[Giles County, Virginia]] school district on behalf of anonymous plaintiffs. A display of the [[Ten Commandments]] had been placed beside a copy of the U.S. Constitution at Giles County public schools. Prior to the suit, in January and June 2011, the FFRF and the ACLU had sent letters to the school board requesting removal of the display. The school superintendent ordered that the displays of the Ten Commandments be removed. The Giles County school board met in June 2011 and voted to overturn the superintendent's decision to remove the display.<ref>{{cite press release | url=https://www.aclu.org/religion-belief/groups-promise-lawsuit-if-giles-county-school-board-orders-reposting-ten | title=Groups promise lawsuit if Giles County School Board orders reposting of Ten Commandments | publisher=[[American Civil Liberties Union]] | date= June 1, 2011 | accessdate= July 30, 2013 | author=<!-- no byline ACLU staff --> |location= Giles County, VA}}</ref> After the suit was filed, the school board in 2012 agreed to remove the display and to pay attorneys' fees.<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Doe 1 et. al v. School Board of Giles County |vol= |reporter= |opinion= 7:11-cv-00435 |date= 2012 |court= W.D. Va.}} [https://ffrf.org/uploads/legal/giles_complaint.pdf Complaint], 2011. Retrieved July 2, 2013.</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Salinas|first=Orlando|title=Settlement reached in Giles Co. Ten Commandments battle|url=http://articles.wdbj7.com/2012-07-02/giles-county-school-board_32461451|work=[[WDBJ]]|date=July 2, 2012|accessdate=July 2, 2013|location=Roanoke/Lynchburg|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130514201024/http://articles.wdbj7.com/2012-07-02/giles-county-school-board_32461451|archivedate=May 14, 2013|df=}}</ref>
In May 2012, the FFRF, acting on a complaint from a resident, asked the city of [[Woonsocket, Rhode Island]], to remove a Latin cross from a World War I and II memorial on public land.<ref>{{cite news |title= Hundreds gather to defend Woonsocket memorial |url= http://www.boston.com/news/local/rhode_island/articles/2012/05/02/rally_planned_in_ri_for_war_memorial_with_cross/ |newspaper= [[The Boston Globe]] |date= May 2, 2012 |agency= Associated Press |last= Niedowski |first= Erika |accessdate= July 3, 2013}}</ref> The city refused to do so. The FFRF states that it is currently looking for a plaintiff in the area to represent for a suit,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.woonsocketcall.com/node/7626 | title=FFRF hasn't changed stance on monument | newspaper=[[The Call (Woonsocket)|The Call]] | date= March 5, 2013 | accessdate= August 1, 2013 | last=Baron |first= Jim |location= Woonsocket, RI}}</ref> which the FFRF have yet to do, citing the difficulty with another case that occurred with another plaintiff in the state, [[Jessica Ahlquist]], in the case [[Ahlquist v. Cranston]].
On July 24, 2012, after receiving a letter from the FFRF, the [[Steubenville, Ohio]], city council decided to remove the image of the Christ the King Chapel at the [[Franciscan University of Steubenville]] from its town logo.<ref>{{cite news |title= Ohio city council removes image of Catholic college from town logo |url= http://cnsnews.com/news/article/ohio-city-council-removes-image-catholic-college-town-logo |last= Burke |first= Patrick |work= [[Cybercast News Service|CNSNews.com]] |date= July 26, 2012 |accessdate= July 3, 2013}}</ref>
In August 2012 the FFRF, on behalf of a resident, threatened a lawsuit challenging a Latin cross that had been displayed on top of the water tower of [[Whiteville, Tennessee]]. After the FFRF wrote three initial letters, but before the lawsuit was filed, the town removed one arm of the cross.<ref>{{cite news |title= Whiteville settles lawsuit over cross atop tower |url= http://www.knoxnews.com/news/2012/aug/10/whiteville-settles-lawsuit-over-cross-atop-tower/ |date= August 10, 2012 |agency= Associated Press |work= [[Knoxville News Sentinel]] |accessdate= July 3, 2013}}</ref> The removal cost the town $4,000, and as part of the settlement the town paid $20,000 in the FFRF's attorneys fees.<ref name="Whiteville Settles Cross Lawsuit">{{cite news |title= Whiteville settles cross lawsuit |url= http://www.wbbjtv.com/news/local/Whiteville-Settles-Cross-Lawsuit-165687916.html |date= August 10, 2012 |author= <!-- no byline 7 Eyewitness News Staff --> |work= [[WBBJ-TV]] |series= 7 Eyewitness News |accessdate= July 2, 2013 |location= [[West Tennessee]] |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131005003029/http://www.wbbjtv.com/news/local/Whiteville-Settles-Cross-Lawsuit-165687916.html |archivedate= October 5, 2013 |df= }}</ref> The town also agreed never to replace the missing arm and not to place other crosses on public property.<ref name="Whiteville Settles Cross Lawsuit"/>
In August 2012 the FFRF, on behalf of a Montana resident, sued the United States Forest Service. A special use permit for the placement of a statue of Jesus on federal land was granted in 1954 at the request of the [[Knights of Columbus]].<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.becketfund.org/mismontanajesuscase/ | title=Media Information Sheet (Montana Jesus Statue – FFRF v. Weber) | publisher=The Becket Fund | accessdate=29 August 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007083351/http://www.becketfund.org/mismontanajesuscase/ | archivedate=7 October 2013 | df= }}</ref> The Forest Service continued to grant renewals of the permit until 2010. When the Service declined to renew, the Knights declined to remove the statue citing "tradition" and the "historical" value of the statue.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://au.org/blogs/wall-of-separation/monumental-mistake-a-statue-of-jesus-in-a-national-forest-violates-church | title=Monumental Mistake: A Statue Of Jesus In A National Forest Violates Church-State Separation | publisher=ACLU | date=11 October 2011 | accessdate=29 August 2013 | author=Brown, Simon}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/25/us/in-montana-jesus-statue-is-focus-of-legal-battle.html?_r=0 | title=Legal Battle Ignites Over Jesus Statue in Montana | publisher=The New York Times | date=24 November 2011 | accessdate=29 August 2013 | author=Frosch, Dan}}</ref> After on-line protests the statue was allowed to stay and the permit granted. The FFRF filed suit in February 2012.<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Freedom From Religion Foundation v. United States Forest Service |vol= |reporter= |opinion= |date= 2012 |court= }} [https://ffrf.org/uploads/legal/BigMountainShrine-complaint.pdf Complaint], February 2012. Retrieved 29 August 2013.</ref> In June 2013, a federal judge found in favor of the defendants, allowing the statue to remain.<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Freedom From Religion Foundation v. United States Forest Service |vol= |reporter= |opinion= |date= 2013 |court= }} [http://wp.patheos.com.s3.amazonaws.com/blogs/friendlyatheist/files/2013/06/2013-06-24-MSJ-Order.pdf Order], 24 June 2013. Retrieved August 29, 2013.</ref> In August 2013, the FFRF filed an appeal of the decision.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://wsau.com/news/articles/2013/aug/26/jesus-statue-in-montana-target-of-freedom-from-religion-foundation/ | title=Jesus statue in Montana target of Freedom From Religion Foundation | publisher=WSAU 550AM | date=26 August 2013 | accessdate=29 August 2013 | author=Lee, Larry}}</ref>
In 2012 the FFRF wrote several letters to Prudhommes Restaurant, in [[Columbia, Pennsylvania]], explaining that offering a 10% discount to Sunday patrons who present a [[church bulletin]] is a violation of state and federal law, specifically the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]]. The individual who brought the matter to the FFRF's attention has filed a discrimination complaint with the Pennsylvania Human Relations. The FFRF is only involved in an advisory capacity.<ref>{{cite news |title= Prudhomme's cites surge of support, patrons after complaint by atheist |url= http://lancasteronline.com/article/local/690280_Prudhomme-s-cites-surge-of-support--patrons-after-complaint-by-atheist.html |date= July 18, 2012 |last= Hilton |first= John |accessdate= July 3, 2013 |newspaper= [[Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.|Intelligencer Journal/Lancaster New Era]] |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131004234539/http://lancasteronline.com/article/local/690280_Prudhomme-s-cites-surge-of-support--patrons-after-complaint-by-atheist.html |archivedate= October 4, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
====Prayer in government/schools==== {{Main|National day of prayer #Legal challenge}} In October 2008, the FFRF filed suit against the U.S. government over the statute establishing the [[National Day of Prayer]] (NDoP). In 2010, Federal judge [[Barbara Brandriff Crabb]] ruled it [[unconstitutional]] as it is "an inherently religious exercise that serves no secular function".<ref name= "NDoP">National Day of Prayer: * {{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/CRIME/04/15/wisconsin.court.prayer/|title=Federal judge strikes down National Day of Prayer statute|last=Gilgoff|first=Dan|date= April 16, 2010|publisher=[[CNN]] | accessdate=July 1, 2013}} * {{cite news |title= Federal judge rules National Day of Prayer unconstitutional |url= http://www.cleveland.com/nation/index.ssf/2010/04/federal_judge_rules_national_d.html |newspaper= [[The Plain Dealer]] |location= Cleveland, OH |agency= Associated Press |last= Richmond |first= Todd |date= April 16, 2010 |accessdate= July 1, 2013}} * {{cite news | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/04/22/legal-skirmish-colors-nat_n_548516.html | title=Legal Skirmish Colors National Day Of Prayer | publisher=The Huffington Post | date=22 June 2010 | accessdate=4 September 2013 | author=Banks, Adelle M.}} </ref> This ruling was appealed by the U.S. government. In April 2011, the U.S. Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals dismissed the FFRF's challenge to the NDoP, holding that the FFRF did not have standing to challenge the NDoP statute or proclamations and that only the President was injured enough to challenge the NDoP statute.<ref name="FFRF v Obama 7th">{{cite court |litigants= Freedom From Religion Foundation v. Obama |date= April 14, 2011 |court= 7th Cir. |opinion= 10–1973 |url= https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-7th-circuit/1209983.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/religion/2011-04-15-prayer_court_14_ST_N.htm |title= Court dismisses challenge to National Day of Prayer |newspaper= [[USA Today]] |date= April 14, 2011 |first= Adelle M. |last= Banks |accessdate= July 3, 2013 |agency= [[Religion News Service]]}}</ref>
The FFRF, in January 2013, after receiving a complaint from a resident, asked the city council of [[Rapid City, South Dakota]], to eliminate its practice of beginning each city council meeting with a Christian prayer. After the FFRF sent a second letter in February 2013, the mayor stated at that time that prayers would continue.<ref>{{cite news |title= Anti-prayer group fires second salvo |url= http://rapidcityjournal.com/news/anti-prayer-group-fires-second-salvo/article_4ec2011c-c9ca-5573-ac08-b5240b7cbd36.html |date= February 17, 2013 |accessdate= July 3, 2013 |last= Orlowski |first= Aaron |newspaper= [[Rapid City Journal]]}}</ref>
===Internal Revenue Service===
====Parish exemption==== The FFRF filed suit against the IRS over the parish exemption that allows "ministers of the gospel" to claim part of their salary as an income-tax-free housing allowance. This was originally filed in 2009, in California,<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Freedom From Religion Foundation, Inc. v. Geithner |vol= 715 |reporter= F.Supp2d. |opinion= 1051 |court= E.D. Cal. |date= May 21, 2010 |url= https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=11603417398422872068&hl=en&as_sdt=2&as_vis=1&oi=scholarr}}</ref><ref>{{cite court |litigants= Freedom From Religion Foundation, Inc. v. Geithner |vol= 644 |reporter= F.3d |opinion= 836 |court= 9th Cir. |date= May 9, 2011 |url= https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=14163518758100128154&q=Freedom+From+Religion+Foundation+v.+Geithner&hl=en&as_sdt=2,10&as_vis=1}}</ref> then subsequently dropped and re-filed in 2011, in Wisconsin,<ref>{{cite news |title= Madison atheists sue to end IRS break to ministers |url=http://www.jsonline.com/blogs/news/129949298.html |last= Vielmetti |first= Bruce |date= September 16, 2011 |newspaper= [[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] |accessdate= July 12, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite court |litigants= Freedom From Religion Foundation v. Geithner |opinion= 11-CV-626 |court= W.D. Wis. |date= 2011}} [http://media.jsonline.com/documents/ReligiousTax.pdf Complaint], September 13, 2011. Retrieved July 12, 2013.</ref> because of standing. In August 2012, a federal judge stated that the suit could go forward. In August 2013, the Justice Department argued that leaders of an atheist group may qualify for the parish exemption. Gaylor states "this is not what we are after,"<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/08/20/atheist-religion-tax-breaks/2678367/ | title=Feds say OK to atheists on religion tax break | newspaper=USA Today | date= August 20, 2013 | accessdate= August 23, 2013 | last=Smietana |first= Bob}}</ref> going on to say that the government should not give religious groups any special treatment.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/peterjreilly/2013/08/18/government-lawyers-advocate-for-atheism-as-a-religion/ | title=Government lawyers advocate For atheism as a religion | publisher=[[Forbes]] |work=Forbes.com | date= August 18, 2013 | accessdate= August 23, 2013 | last=Reilly |first= Peter J.}}</ref>
On November 21, 2013, a federal judge ruled in the FFRF's favor.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://host.madison.com/wsj/news/local/with-court-ruling-clergy-housing-allowances-come-in-for-intense/article_aa394ca8-336d-57ab-8724-bd8d83361f74.html | title=With court ruling, clergy housing allowances come in for intense scrutiny | publisher=Wisconsin State Journal | date=22 December 2013 | accessdate=25 December 2013 | author=Erickson, Doug}}</ref><ref>{{cite court |litigants= FFRF, Inc., Annie Laurie Gaylor and Dan Barker, v. Jacob Lew and Daniel Werfel |vol= |reporter= |opinion= |pinpoint= |court=W.D. Wis. |date=23 November 2013 |url=https://ffrf.org/images/FFRF%20v%20Geithner%20-%20Parsonage%20Exemption.pdf |accessdate=25 December 2013 |quote= }}</ref> In January 2014, the Department of Justice filed an appeal in federal court.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.abpnews.com/culture/politics/item/28280-obama-administration-to-appeal-clergy-tax-ruling | title=Obama administration to appeal clergy tax ruling | publisher=apdnews.com | date=27 January 2014 | accessdate=26 February 2014 | author=Dilday, Robert}}</ref> In November 2014, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit issued its decision, concluding that the federal tax code provision that treats church-provided housing allowances to ministers as income tax-free must stand.<ref>{{cite web |title=Appeals Court Rejects Atheist Challenge to the Clergy Housing Exclusion |date=November 13, 2014 |publisher=Evangelical Council for Financial Accountability |url=http://www.ecfa.org/Content/Appeals-Court-Rejects-Atheist-Challenge-to-the-Clergy-Housing-Exclusion}}</ref>
====Electioneering==== In November 2012, The FFRF filed a lawsuit against the IRS for not enforcing its own [[electioneering]] laws. The FFRF cited in its suit the placement of full page ads by the Billy Graham Evangelistic Association; the diocese requiring priests to read a statement urging Catholics to vote; and the institution of "Pulpit Freedom Sunday". The group claimed that not enforcing the federal tax codes that prohibit tax-exempt religious organizations from electioneering is a violation of the First Amendment of the Constitution.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/nov/20/us-churches-tax-exemption-faithbased-politics? | title=How US churches exploit tax exemption to promote faith-based politics | date=November 20, 2012 | accessdate=July 12, 2013 | last=Stewart | first=Katherine |authorlink=Kathern Stewart| newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.isthmus.com/isthmus/article.php?article=38282 | title=Freedom From Religion Foundation sues IRS for not enforcing electioneering restrictions on churches | newspaper=[[Isthmus (newspaper)|Isthmsus]] |series= The Daily Page | date= November 14, 2012 | accessdate= August 23, 2013 | last=Davidoff |first= Judith}}</ref> The group stated that the increasing involvement of religious institutions in politics was "blatantly and deliberately flaunting the electioneering restrictions".<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/11/15/freedom-from-religion-foundation-lawsuit_n_2138457.html | title=Freedom From Religion Foundation sues IRS over political activity by churches, religious groups | work=[[The Huffington Post]] | date= November 15, 2012 | accessdate= August 23, 2013 | last=Bauer |first= Scott}}</ref> The IRS had filed a motion to dismiss in federal court, but in August 2013 it was decided that the lawsuit could proceed stating that the FFRF "has standing to seek an order requiring the IRS to treat religious organizations no more favorably than it treats the Foundation".<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/08/21/atheists-lawsuit-irs_n_3792145.html | title=Atheists can sue IRS over failure to enforce limits on churches' political speech | work=The Huffington Post | date= August 21, 2013 | accessdate= August 23, 2013 | last=Wing |first= Nick}}</ref>
====990 Form==== In December 2012 the FFRF filed suit against the IRS for not requiring the yearly filing of a 990 Form for religious institutions, which is required for all other non-profit organizations.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.thedailypage.com/daily/article.php?article=38645 | title=Freedom From Religion Foundation sues IRS for not requiring churches to annually maintain tax-exempt status | newspaper=Isthmus |series= The Daily Page | date= December 28, 2012 | accessdate= August 23, 2013 | last=Davidoff |first= Judith}}</ref> This action is pending.

===Wisconsin=== The FFRF maintains a sign in the [[Wisconsin State Capitol]] during the Christmas season, which reads:<ref>{{cite news |last= Thibault |first= Kate |title= Foundation adds to holiday display |url= http://badgerherald.com/news/2007/12/05/foundation_adds_to_h.php |newspaper=The Badger Herald |location= Madison, WI |date= December 5, 2007 | accessdate= July 3, 2013}}</ref> {{cquote|At this season of THE WINTER SOLSTICE may reason prevail.<br> There are no gods, no devils, no angels, no heaven or hell.<br> There is only our natural world.<br> Religion is but myth and superstition that hardens hearts and enslaves minds.}}
In 2013, a natural nativity featuring [[Charles Darwin]], [[Albert Einstein]] and [[Mark Twain]] as the three wise men, the [[Statue of Liberty]] and an astronaut as angels and an African American girl baby doll to represent that "humankind was birthed in Africa" was added.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.startribune.com/lifestyle/homegarden/234973441.html | title=Holiday displays at Wisconsin Capitol include Festivus pole, atheists' nativity scene | publisher=Star Tribune | date=8 December 2013 | accessdate=25 December 2013 | author=Bauer, Scott|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20131225164211/www.startribune.com/lifestyle/homegarden/234973441.html|archivedate=25 December 2013}}</ref>
===Rhode Island=== In 2013, the FFRF was allowed to place a sign in the rotunda, after complaints from its members, as a response to the crèches and other religious symbols that are already in place at the statehouse.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.pawtuckettimes.com/content/atheists-statehouse-display-generates-another-yule-controversy | title=Atheists' Statehouse display generates another Yule controversy | publisher=The Times | date=17 December 2013 | accessdate=25 December 2013 | author=Baron, Jim | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20131225172323/http://www.pawtuckettimes.com/content/atheists-statehouse-display-generates-another-yule-controversy | archivedate=25 December 2013 | df= }}</ref>
===Dayton, Tennessee===
On July 14, 2017, a statue of [[Clarence Darrow]] was unveiled in [[Dayton, Tennessee]] on the [[Rhea County Courthouse]] lawn, funded by a $150,000 donation from the FFRF. The courthouse was the site of the historic 1925 [[Scopes Monkey Trial]] wherein Darrow unsuccessfully defended a teacher, [[John T. Scopes]], who was found guilty of teaching evolution in a public school in violation of what was then a Tennessee state law. The statue was placed just a few feet away from a statue of [[William Jennings Bryan]], Darrow's [[creationist]] opponent in the trial, which had been erected in 2005 by nearby [[Bryan College]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/14/us/darrow-bryan-dayton-tennessee-scopes-statues.html |title=At Site of Scopes Trial, Darrow Statue Belatedly Joins Bryan's |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |date= |accessdate=2017-07-15}}</ref>
===Athens, Texas===
In 2011 the FFRF was contacted by a local Austin citizen regarding the placement of a nativity scene on [[Henderson County, Texas|Henderson County]] courthouse property.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.athensreview.com/local/x942842875/Atheist-sues-City-over-Nativity-scene | title=Atheist sues city over nativity scene | newspaper=[[Athens Daily Review]] | date= December 4, 2012 | accessdate= July 14, 2013 | last=Flowers |first= Rich}}</ref> A letter of complaint was sent. After it was decided that the nativity scene would remain, the FFRF petitioned to have its own banner placed on the site, but county officials declined to discuss its placement. The FFRF banner was placed without permission on the courthouse property, but was soon removed.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.kltv.com/story/17674661/navitity-scene-to-stay | title=ETX Nativity scene approved for 2012, atheist banner still pending | station=[[KLTV]] | date= May 8, 2012 | accessdate= July 14, 2013 | last1=Torre |first1= Melanie |last2= Compton |first2= Kerri |network= [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |location= Tyler, TX}}</ref> In April 2012 the request to place the banner was denied.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.athensreview.com/local/x253554340/County-judge-denies-FFRF-s-request | title=County judge denies FFRF's request | newspaper=Athens Daily Review | date= October 12, 2012 | accessdate= July 14, 2013 | last=Flowers |first= Rich}}</ref> {{clear}}
==''Freethought Radio''== Freethought Radio, called the "only weekly Freethought radio broadcast anywhere", is an hour-long show broadcast live on [[WXXM-FM]] Saturdays at 11 a.m. CDT. It had also been broadcast on [[Air America Radio|Air America]] before that service ceased operation in March, 2010. The show is hosted by the co-presidents of FFRF, [[Dan Barker]] and [[Annie Laurie Gaylor]]. Regular features include "Theocracy Alert" and "Freethinkers Almanac". The latter highlights historic freethinkers, many of whom are also songwriters. The show's intro and outro make use of [[John Lennon]]'s "[[Imagine (John Lennon song)|Imagine]]", which has an [[antireligious]] theme. A [[podcast]] archive is available at the FFRF website.<ref>{{cite news |title= Out, atheist and American |url= https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/belief/2009/aug/04/atheism-us-religion-hypatia? |last= McCarthy |first= Susan |date= August 4, 2009 |newspaper= [[The Guardian]] |accessdate= July 12, 2013}}</ref>

==Charitable rating and finances==
Charity Navigator gives FFRF a four star rating and reports in 2013 FFRF had revenues of $3,878,938 USD, with a net surplus (after expenses) of $1,715,563 and net assets of $11,519,770. Officer compensation for the "co-presidents" husband and wife Dan Barker and Annie Laurie Gaylor was $88,700 and $86,500 ($175,200 combined) or approximately 10% of the net surplus.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.summary&orgid=7003|title=Charity Navigator Rating - Freedom From Religion Foundation|work=Charity Navigator}}</ref>

'''Gotthard Günther''' (15 June 1900 – 29 November 1984), was a [[Germany|German]] (Prussian)<ref name="Asimov"/> [[Philosophy|philosopher]].
== Biography == Günther was born in [[Miłków, Lower Silesian Voivodeship|Arnsdorf]], [[Hirschberg im Riesengebirge]], [[Prussian Silesia]] (modern day [[Jelenia Góra County|Jelenia Góra]], [[Poland]]). From 1921 to 1933, Günther studied [[sinology]] and [[philosophy]] at the universities of [[Heidelberg]] and [[Berlin]], and wrote his doctor's thesis on [[Hegel]] in 1933 under the guidance of [[Eduard Spranger]]. From 1935 to 1937, he worked at the institute of [[Arnold Gehlen]] at the [[University of Leipzig]], publishing “''Christliche Metaphysik und das Schicksal des modernen Bewusstseins''” (“Christian metaphysics and the fate of modern consciousness”, together with [[Helmut Schelsky]] in 1937). He was a member of the [[Leipzig school (sociology)|Leipzig School]].
In the same year, following his wife, the Jewish psychologist Dr. Marie Günther-Hendel, he emigrated from Germany first to [[Italy]], afterwards to [[Stellenbosch University]] in [[South Africa]] and, in 1940, to the [[United States of America|United States]]. There he completed his system of place-valued logics and morphogrammatics. His great study “''Die philosophische Idee einer nicht-Aristotelischen Logik''” (“The philosophical concept of a non-Aristotelian logic”) went to print in 1957 (Hamburg, Meiner). As a research professor, he joined the department of [[electrical engineering]] at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] in 1960, working together with [[Warren Sturgis McCulloch]], [[Heinz von Foerster]], [[Humberto Maturana]] and others. In 1962, he published ''Cybernetic ontology and transjunctional operations''. Later he lectured at the University of Hamburg until he died in that city, in 1984.
According to Isaac Asimov, who considered Gunther "a good friend," Gunther "felt that civilization was a product of the Old World and could not flourish indigenously in the New."<ref name="Asimov">''In Memory Yet Green.'' [[Isaac Asimov]]. 1979 p. 605.</ref> Asimov noted that Gunther thus "maintained [that] when Old World civilization was transplanted to the New World, a distortion was introduced and one of the ways in which this distortion was evidenced was by the peculiar American invention of science fiction, which was not to be confused with earlier European ventures in the field (i.e., Jules Vernes)."<ref name="Asimov"/>
==Work and legacy== Günther's work was based upon [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel]], [[Martin Heidegger]] and [[Oswald Spengler]]. He developed a trans-[[Aristotle|Aristotelian]] logical approach (omitting the ''[[Law of excluded middle|tertium non datur]]''). Günther's [[transclassical logic]] was the attempt to combine improved results of modern dialectic with formal logic. His focus on the philosophical problem of the "Du" ("You"/"Thou") was trailblazing. He also contributed to the fields of [[cybernetics]] and to both natural and social sciences, especially to [[sociology]].
His œuvre (body of work), in German and English, is quite substantial. An overview can be gathered from his three volumes, helping make dialectics operationable (see below). He was of influence in the areas of philosophy, cybernetics, mathematics, and sociology. As of 2004, the Gotthard Günther Research Center (“Gotthard-Günther-Forschungsstelle”) is working at the [[University of Klagenfurt]] in Austria.
==References== <references/>
== Publications == * 1933, ''Grundzüge einer neuen Theorie des Denkens in Hegels Logik'' [Fundamentals of a Theory of Thinking in Hegel's Logic]. Second, expanded edition, with a new foreword. Hamburg: Meiner, 1978. {{ISBN|3-7873-0435-5}}. * 1937, ''Christliche Metaphysik und das Schicksal des modernen Bewusstseins''. Leipzig: Hirzel. * 1952, ''Uberwindung von Raum und Zeit: phantastische Geschichten aus der Welt von Morgen''. Düsseldorf: Karl Rauch. * 1957, ''Das Bewusstsein der Maschinen: eine Metaphysik der Kybernetik''. Krefeld, Baden-Baden: Agis-Verlag. Second, expanded edition 1963. Third edition as ''Das Bewusstsein der Maschinen: eine Metaphysik der Kybernetik, mit einem Beitrag aus dem Nachlass: "Erkennen und Wollen"'', edited by Eberhard von Goldammer and Joachim Paul. Baden-Baden: Agis-Verlag, 2002. {{ISBN|3-87007-009-9}}. French edition, as ''La conscience des machines: une métaphysique de la cybernétique; suivi de Cognition et volition'', third edition, edited by Eberhard von Goldammer and Joachim Paul, translated by Françoise Parrot and Engelbert Kronthaler, Paris: l'Harmattan, 2008. * 1959, ''Idee und Grundriss einer nicht-Aristotelischen Logik, Bd. 1. Die Idee und ihre philosophischen Voraussetzungen''. [Idea and Outline of a Non-Aristotelian Logic, vol. 1: The Idea and Its Philosophical Postulates]. Hamburg: F. Meiner. Second, revised edition, Hamburg: F. Meiner, 1978. Third edition, as ''Idee und Grundriss einer nicht-Aristotelischen Logik: die Idee und ihre philosophischen Voraussetzungen: mit einem Anhang Das Phänomen der Orthogonalität, und mit einem Fragment aus dem Nachlass Die Metamorphose der Zahl''. Hamburg: Meiner, 1991. {{ISBN|3-7873-1033-9}}. * 1962, ''Cybernetic Ontology and Transjunctional Operations''. University of Illinois, Engineering Experiment Station. Technical Report no. 4. Urbana: Electrical Engineering Research Laboratory, University of Illinois. * 1965, ''Cybernetics and the Transition from Classical to Trans-Classical Logic''. Illinois University Biological Computer Laboratory BCL Report 3.0. Urbana: Biological Computer Laboratory, University of Illinois. * 1967, ''Logik, Zeit, Emanation und Evolution''. Arbeitsgemeinschaft für Forschung des Landes Nordrhein-Westfalen. Geistwissenschaften 136. Cologne-Opladen: Westdeutscher Verlag. * 1976, ''Beiträge zur Grundlegung einer operationsfähigen Dialektik, 1'' (Contributions to the Foundation of an Operational Dialectic, 1). Hamburg: Meiner. {{ISBN|3-7873-0371-5}}. * 1979, ''Beiträge zur Grundlegung einer operationsfähigen Dialektik, 2'', (Contributions to the Foundation of an Operational Dialectic, 2) * 1980, ''Beiträge zur Grundlegung einer operationsfähigen Dialektik, 3'', (Contributions to the Foundation of an Operational Dialectic, 3)
==Further reading== *Actual research on polycontextural theories is documented at [http://www.thinkartlab.com ThinkArt Lab] Glasgow, Scotland. *A comprehensive archive of Gunther's work (mainly out of print) is made accessible by [http://www.vordenker.de/gunther_web/gunther_web.htm Vordenker]. *A first insight into the terminology of Gunther's work is offered by the interactive [http://www.thinkartlab.com/pkl/glossary/framed.htm Glossary].

'''Hans-Georg Backhaus''' (born 1929) is a German [[Marxian economist]] and philosopher. He is considered one of the most important theorists on the field of [[Karl Marx|Marx's]] [[Labor theory of value#Marx.27s contribution|theory of value]]. He began a long-term cooperation with [[Helmut Reichelt]] already from his years of university studies.
==Selected publications==
===Main work=== * Backhaus, Hans-Georg: ''Dialektik der Wertform. Untersuchungen zur Marxschen Ökonomiekritik''. Freiburg i. Br. 1997.
===Further publications=== * {{cite journal | url= | author=Hans-Georg Backhaus | title=Zur Marxschen 'Revolutionierung' und 'Kritik' der Ökonomie: Die Bestimmung ihres Gegenstandes als Ganzes 'verrückter Formen' | journal=Mehrwert: Beiträge zur Kritik der politischen Ökonomie | volume=25 | number= | pages=7—35 | month= | year=1984 | language=de }} * Backhaus, Hans-Georg: ''Über den Doppelsinn der Begriffe „Politische Ökonomie“ und „Kritik“ bei Marx und in der Frankfurter Schule''. In: Wolfgang Harich zum Gedächtnis. Eine Gedenkschrift in zwei Bänden. Hrsg. von Stefan Dornuf und Reinhard Pitsch. Bd. 2. München 2000, S. 12-213.
==Bibliography== * Eldred, Michael [http://www.arte-fact.org/ccfbdspf.html Critique of competitive freedom and the bourgeois-democratic state] Copenhagen: Kurasje, 1984 {{ISBN|87-87437-40-6}}. * Bonefeld, Werner: [http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3780/is_199810/ai_n8811709/print ''Dialektik der Wertform: Untersuchungen zur marxschen Okonomiekritik''] (The Dialectic of the Value Form: Investigations into Marx's Critique of Economics). * Bonefeld, Werner: [http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3780/is_200110/ai_n9001732/print ''Kapital and its subtitle: A note on the meaning of critique''.] * Kubota, Ken: [http://www.eulederminerva.de/files/Ken%20Kubota%20-%20Die%20dialektische%20Darstellung%20des%20allgemeinen%20Begriffs%20des%20Kapitals%20im%20Lichte%20der%20Philosophie%20Hegels.pdf ''Die dialektische Darstellung des allgemeinen Begriffs des Kapitals im Lichte der Philosophie Hegels. Zur logischen Analyse der politischen Ökonomie unter besonderer Berücksichtigung Adornos und der Forschungsergebnisse von Rubin, Backhaus, Reichelt, Uno und Sekine''] (PDF), in: Beiträge zur Marx-Engels-Forschung. Neue Folge 2009, pp. 199–224. {{doi|10.4444/100.100.de}}.
==External links== * Verified, continuously updated [http://www.metzger-riehn.de/kt/#Backhaus selected bibliography] with links and materials.
